content: SECTION 1. ADDITIONAL CERTIFICATION REGARDING DRUG-PRODUCING AND DRUG-TRANSIT COUNTRIES. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subparagraph requiring countries to cooperate with the United States in achieving compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Countries must show progress in meeting related plans, programs, and timetables. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to cooperate with the US in meeting the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Countries must demonstrate progress in fulfilling related plans and timetables. Amendments include inserting references to subparagraphs and subsections in the Act. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to cooperate with the US in meeting the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Amendments include additional requirements relating to qualified certification, such as convening a high-level contact group for countries certified under subsection (b)(1)(B). Certification requires a high-level contact group to be convened for countries certified under subsection (b)(1)(B), consisting of key officials from the US and the country. The group is responsible for establishing specific benchmarks for each plan, program, and timetable. Each high-level contact group should establish achievable benchmarks for a country to verify progress under specific plans, programs, and timetables. Benchmarks must include measurable goals related to arrests, extradition, eradication of drug-related crops, and money-laundering. The high-level contact group must set achievable benchmarks for countries, including goals on arrests, extradition, eradication of drug-related crops, and money-laundering, with specified timeframes. A benchmark report must be submitted to Congress annually by the President. The President must establish benchmarks for countries on arrests, extradition, eradication of drug-related crops, and money-laundering, with progress reports submitted to Congress annually. The emphasis will be on the country's progress in meeting these benchmarks for future certifications. In future certifications, the President will prioritize a country's progress on established benchmarks. Congress suggests convening a high-level contact group for Mexico in 1998, with provisions applying to activities and certification in 1999.
